title: 107_hr1623
content: The Act may be cited as the "Historically Women's Public Colleges or Universities Historic Building Restoration and Preservation Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, including "historically women's public college or university," "historic building or structure," and "Secretary." SEC. 3. Preservation and restoration grants for historic buildings and structures at historically women's public colleges or universities. The Secretary awards grants to historically women's public colleges for preserving historic buildings using funds from the National Historic Preservation Act. Grantees must agree to not alter the property without the Secretary's approval. The Secretary may award grants for preserving historic buildings to women's public colleges under the National Historic Preservation Act. Grantees must allow public access for interpretive and educational purposes and provide matching funds for buildings listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Funding for historic building preservation grants requires non-Federal entities to cover 50 percent of program costs, which can include in-kind contributions. Up to $16,000,000 annually is available for grants from 2002 to 2006, with $2,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 2002. $2,000,000 allocated for each of the following universities in different states for historic building preservation grants. Less than $16,000,000 available annually for grants from 2002 to 2006. For fiscal years 2002-2006, if less than $16,000,000 is available, grants to institutions will be reduced. Funds for 2003-2006 will be distributed uniformly to eligible grantees. The Secretary will create necessary regulations for implementation.
